intro: Silene nocturna var. corollina, commonly known as the night-flowering catchfly, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its pink to purple flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has slender, branched stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are tubular with five reflexed lobes, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. It thrives in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges.
